Example 1 Title: Wellbeing in Germany, The Federal Government Germany (2016)
Example 1 Description:
Different types of visualisations in the online publication "Wellbeing
in Germany".

Example 1 Title: Early Childhood Education and Care in Europe, Eurydice / EACEA (2019)
Example 1 Description: In Eurydice Publication on Early Childhood Education and Care, a table is often shown alongside the visualisation (see, for example, p. 30).
Our World in Data offers tooltips to read the single data values. In addition, you can switch between a chart, a map, and a table view.
The charts from Our World in Data contain their logo, the link to the chart's main topic, and even the license for reuse.
Media organisations, such as The Guardian, usually state the name of their organisation as the author directly beneath the visualisation.
Our World in Data provides a short source description below each chart, as well as a longer source description under the tab "sources".
Our World in Data provides the option to download both a PNG and an SVG – and has nice little descriptions of what the user can do with those formats.
The charts in this toolkit always have a source stated below them.
The toolkit offers a simple download button next to each chart to download a PNG.
